‚Äã@EbonyPope Khalil was already let into the country. This didn't happen at a border or port of entry while he was trying to get in. He had a visa. (Student, not a "green card" which is for guest workers.) 

Visas generally cannot be revoked "for any reason". They can be revoked for specific reasons, and the laws about what those are can actually get fairly complicated. Hence the involvement of courts. 

Due process is not a frivolous luxury, and its purpose is not to be a pleasant subjective experience for the accused person. Its purpose is to ensure that government agents do not get away with lying. This is exactly why it HAS to be applied in all relevant cases, not treated as a special privilege of any special class of people, including citizens as opposed to non-citizens. Ensuring it gets applied in all cases is in the self-interest of everyone in the country, because it protects us all against the risk of being victims of government corruption. 

If it is actually true that Khalil incited a riot, then there will (due to the nature of riots) be a huge amount of easily obtained evidence that unequivocally proves he incited a riot. If inciting riots is a legitimate reason to revoke a legal immigrant's visa, then all the government needs to do to revoke Khalil's visa is go to a court hearing and show the judge all the evidence they collected that proves Khalil incited a riot. 

If the government does not want to do this, the most likely explanation is that they know they can't prove the accusation they're making. 

Saying "not everyone should get due process" is tantamount to saying "the government should be allowed to get away with making false accusations at least some of the time." 

Is that really what anyone making this argument believes?

replies.author: @Blackiston
replies.text:
‚Äã@EbonyPope How are they supposed to know if you're a citizen or not if you're not getting due process? Due process, in regards to immigration, is the process to determine whether someone is or isn't supposed to be here. Arguing we shouldn't give these people due process means any administration could grab citizens off the street and deport them without a trial because they never proved to a judge that the person was here illegally. There is a process we're supposed to follow for deportation, and that process is meant to protect us, not the illegals. Do you really want to risk giving a potential far-left future president the power to send citizens off to foreign prisons with no evidence of wrong-doing? Of course not. 

In the case of Khalil, he was not deported by a judge. The administration deported him without proving in a court of law that he should not be here. They even admitted that he was deported by mistake before doubling down on not allowing him back.

I'm always amazed that you people claim to love the constitution and yet you clearly understand none of it. The text of the constitution is clear. All people, not just citizens, are granted a right to due process in the United States.

Be better.

replies.author: @seanmatthewking
replies.text:
"America was never a democracy"
Who is educating these people? Democracy is a large umbrella including imperfect democracies (which is every actual democracy) but not entirely fake democracies (Russia and other authoritarian states that perform mock elections).

US democracy has a lot of problems and has been trending in the wrong direction for quite awhile. But it's still a democracy. There is still something worth fighting for. You have to preserve what we have in order to get the chance to improve it. 

Let's say the US is a 5 on a scale of 1-10, with 10 being the perfect democracy. Yes it would be great to be a 10, but getting knocked back to 0 is so much worse than being an imperfect 5.

replies.author: @seanmatthewking
replies.text:
Another comment said "it's barely a democracy, women and poc got the right to vote very recently." Women got the right over 100 years ago, that's not very recently in the history of a country that's been established for 250 years. The right for poc was 1870, although truly, it was not until 1965 that the right was given reality. 60 years ago, but sure, it's sort of recent. 

To look at the progress this country has made with respect to democracy and rights, and other areas and to glibly say "it's barely a democracy" in the context of US citizens and others worrying that the democracy is slipping away shows me you don't care about poc voting rights or women's voting rights because you dont care about any of it.

author: @BinaryReader
text: It has been observed that the Trump administration will push openly outlandish policies, only to have them partially reversed later. The tactic is used to warm the public warm to the policy, and where partial reversal is observed as a return to normal. The key is bolster public perception and to diminish anger directed at those these policies serve. The most recent example of this is China trade tariffs which have just been cut by 110%, but there is still a 30% tariff applied. The perception is that things are back to normal, but US citizens are still paying a massive 30% import tax, which would be an unthinkable additional cost prior to the Trump administration.

@jojoeljefe0001 You're not really making sense, dude, and since liberal democracy is the only system currently in existence anywhere that isn't dictatorship, those are the only two options we have for the time being, for all practical purposes. 

If democracy ends in the USA any time in the foreseeable future, it's not going to be replaced by any kind of anarcho-communist utopia. It's going to be replaced by a hyper-militarized police state led by either an aristo-bureaucratic oligarchy or an autocratic dictator, built around a repressive religious and/or ethnonationalist ideology. We were halfway there already 20 years ago. That's the reality we're in. 

Calling an analysis of the warning signs that the switch to full-blown fascism may be imminent or underway a "terrible take" just because you don't think liberal democracy is what you'd choose as an imagined ideal system of government makes no sense. 

Since we're all thinking about the Weimar Republic, have you ever heard of the slogan "Nach Hitler Uns"?

replies.author: @jojoeljefe0001
replies.text:
@macdeus2601 i understand what you're saying and as i acknowledged, the conversation im presenting is idealistic, and i recognize my initial interpretation was reactive. 

"a terrible take" is less what i meant but it's what i said, so to rephrase i would say that the point in this video was rather flat. seemingly nuanced but largely biased towards this idea of "civilization", over collective/community. (from an anthropological standpoint, that is itself eurocentric) 

for when we prioritize nations and legitimize rule of law in nations that have turned their back on them, i find it to be a dangerous tool for normalization,  rather than action towards actual structural change.(think the pendulum of ideology in administrations, i.e: obama, trump, biden, trump) trump is the catalyst rather than the singularity. 

in a post trump world, what should come next is not a return to normalcy, or a readoption of liberal democracy, it just doesnt work. especially at such a large scale like this United States project. this nation needs to be dismantled back to concepts of vast landscapes and returned to the stewards that have been displaced and disregarded. 

and of course the transition period will not be smooth, as it never is. but we must move forward with a different framework that prioritize the needs and interests of the collective through empowerment of land ownership and release of agriculture back to local communities. 

(also i see why you proposed that phrase  "Nach Hitler Uns" to me, and no i hadn't heard of it before but i will definitely do a deeper reading. but with the surface research for this reply i will say that's not what i'm getting at.)

author: @black_forest_
text:
Congrats on becoming a dad!!!

I have lost my own father at the beginning of this year. In the weeks after I went through his old stuff in the basement. Finding all his political books and magazine, photos from trips to the DDR, to the West Sahara on aid missions for the Sahrawis, who he worked to support in their anti-colonial struggle, photos of him at a "Die Gr√ºne" podium giving speeches about disarmament, photos from Brokdorf 1981, stories from how he gave speeches in school informing classmates about Allende... 
I just want to say that having a dad who isnt quiet about the pains of his time, who picks every fight against injustice he can, has really filled me with pride and has given me motivation to follow in those footsteps as best I can. You are doing amazing and I wish all the best for you and your families future <3

The comical part is that both sides are filling yanks' heads with hypernormalized garbage that normal people who don't have an ounce of critical thinking will ever try to check for themselves. Both sides just think the other is brainwashed. They just take these headlines and vague news without context and accept it as fact. 

Example: The news in the US (depending on what party owns them) uses suspiciously flowery language about a "Maryland dad," or simplified/vague language like "Spokane man" in headlines to make you think that they're innocent people just caught up in Trump's tyrannical web of deportations, but court records are public. Even people in other countries can access them. I was able to find and read them; and found that the news headlines are trying to steer the narrative and make it seem like the US President is trying to detain innocent people. It took me a few clicks to find out that was a lie by the news, by omission. The sensationalism is absolutely mental with US news media.

The fact that the US has news like this, paid for by these big corporations, and that viewers just accept it as fact without thinking or asking questions, just shows me that neither party's members have any idea what they're doing or what's real. This final suit was postponed due to his running in the 2024 Election and Judge Cannons interesting decision to state that a Special Counsel was unconstitutionally appointed (against longstanding precedent that allowed counsel as first seen during Watergate)

And the breaking laws every day is through his Executive Orders

While it is true that executive orders are constitutional, the content of the executive orders are not. 

Executive Orders are NOT constitutional laws. For example, you cannot get rid of money allocated from Congress to anybody unless Congress gives permission. 

This is due to Article 1 Section 8 Clause 3 of the US Constitution the Commerce Clause which gives Congress the sole power to ‚ÄúRegulate Commerce‚Ä¶ among the several States‚Äù. additionally, under the Impoundment Control Act of 1947, in order for the President to terminate Congressional spending, they must formally ask Congress for permission to pause spending.

@ScandinavianHeretic¬† ok sure. How long should we wait and what should we look out for to determine if it is or becomes real?

What should I do and live my life in 2025 and beyond according to you?

replies.author: @ScandinavianHeretic
replies.text:
@SETHthegodofchaos A fair question, finally - so I‚Äôll give you a straight answer.

Start by asking yourself this: what would oppression actually look like if it weren‚Äôt dressed in black leather and marching in step? Would it announce itself with banners, or slide in wearing a badge marked "safety"?

Watch for mechanisms, not metaphors. Don‚Äôt look for Darth Vader, look for bureaucrats demanding more speech controls ‚Äúfor your protection,‚Äù banks debanking people for political views, platforms erasing dissent, laws written so vaguely they can mean anything the enforcer wants.

Oppression now doesn‚Äôt need boots. It wears a ‚Äúterms of service.‚Äù

What should you do? Simple but not easy:


 * Speak plainly, even when it's unfashionable.
 * Refuse to mistake collective emotion for truth.
 * Stop outsourcing your sense of danger to fictional scripts and algorithm-curated feeds.
 * Build something real: thinking, skills, community, clarity.

You asked how we‚Äôll know it‚Äôs real? You'll know when saying what you're saying now comes with a cost higher than being called a ‚Äúbot.‚Äù The irony is that by quoting fiction instead of analyzing facts, many are welcoming that future with open arms.

You wanted to live in a meaningful time? You do. The question is whether you‚Äôll meet it with your eyes open.

replies.author: @ScandinavianHeretic
replies.text:
@SETHthegodofchaos Fair question, so here‚Äôs a real answer.

Oppression doesn‚Äôt always come marching in boots. These days, it shows up with a smile and a ‚Äúterms of service.‚Äù

Don‚Äôt look for villains in capes. Look for policies that limit speech "for safety," accounts shut down over opinions, or vague rules that shift depending on who's in charge.

What to do?

   * Speak clearly, even when it's unpopular

   * Don‚Äôt mistake group emotion for truth

   * Stop quoting fiction like it's evidence

   * Build something real: skills, thinking, community

You‚Äôll know it‚Äôs ‚Äúreal‚Äù when saying these things costs more than a downvote or an insult. And the irony? Quoting movie lines instead of examining facts is how people accidentally open the door to the very thing they fear.

You wanted to live in serious times. You do. The question is, will you respond seriously?

I hate to say it, but Mr Chaplin was wrong.

He was optimistic, as he should have been. He sought to provide hope during a time of great agony. But he was factually wrong.

Greed never passed, power was never returned to the people. Men died, and liberty kept dying with it.

Greed never passed because the capitalist machine marched full steam ahead. Each decade saw privatisation increase and public funding decrease. It saw taxes on the wealthy decrease and taxes on the worker increase. Then came neoliberalism and so began the great transfer of wealth from the working class to the top 1%. We are in the final throes of that transfer now and we are facing an economic collapse that may just dwarf that of 1929.

When the war ended, evil was not defeated - a single evil was defeated. But a few great evils remained. Fascism never died, it went into hiding and it did so in the United States, Russia and Britain. Immediately after the war ended, Britain established Israel, and facilitated their century long genocide.

The U.S continued to facilitate Jim Crow in the South and barbaric segregation in the North. The eugenics that Hitler enforced were used in the United States during this time. Black boys were lynched. Some had their body parts removed and were consumed by these ravenous mobs. During the same time, the U.S was also supporting South Africa's (my country) apartheid regime. Reagan and Thatcher were undying supporters of what we did here because their benefactors wanted to emulate it again in Britain and the U.S.

Currently, the U.S is helping Russia, a fascist state, to take over Ukraine. They are empowering Israel, a fascist state, in finishing their genocide of Palestinians and they have been for nearly a century. The U.S toppled countless Democratic governments because the goals of those governments did not align with the capital interests of their benefactors.

Antisemitism is on the rise, has been for a while, and we picked up on it too late with Charlottesville. And now a fascist regime has taken hold of the most militarily powerful nation on the planet, whom nobody will challenge simply because of mutually assured destruction.

What Hitler dreamed of, is now being fulfilled through a vassal state, the United States. The U.S will finish what Hitler started. The Nazis never died, they weren't defeated, they merely retreated and they rebuilt and planned and have now taken over. And now they have evolved into something far more robust and terrifying. Now it is not just the Jew, the Romani, the homosexual, the Freemason, the feeble, the non white, that is being targeted. It is the worker, indiscriminately it is the worker. The undesirables are going to be killed and what is left? Will be made slaves. With the erosion of labour rights and civil rights, employees will become property.

What we are in for will dwarf what Germany did. What we are in for is the vengeance of the failed third reich.

replies.author: @ScandinavianHeretic
replies.text:
@hataranneulastr5376 You're making my point for me, even if you don‚Äôt realize it.

Trump wasn‚Äôt musing about scrapping the Constitution because he finds it boring - he was expressing frustration that if constitutional guarantees apply in every single immigration case (illegal too), then the system is functionally paralyzed by its own design. That may be an unpleasant observation, but it‚Äôs not a declaration of tyranny. It's a critique of logistical absurdity.

If you think this exposes some unique contempt for the rule of law, I‚Äôd invite you to review how prior administrations handled mass deportations or indefinite detentions. The inconsistency isn't in Trump - it's in how selectively people apply their outrage.

As for your moral absolutism: yes, the Constitution grants due process. But due process, like any principle, must exist in tension with practicality. If the law can‚Äôt scale to reality, then the question isn‚Äôt whether someone ‚Äúhates the Constitution,‚Äù it‚Äôs whether the Constitution as applied is equipped to deal with scale, complexity, and security.

Your final point unwittingly gives the game away: maybe mass deportation is un-Constitutional in spirit. Ah, so now we‚Äôre in the realm of ‚Äúspirit,‚Äù not law. But you began by saying Trump is breaking the law. Which is it?

Context matters. Without it, you‚Äôre not making an argument. You‚Äôre performing certainty to feel righteous - and that‚Äôs the kind of politics that hollows out democracy far faster than one man‚Äôs clumsy phrasing.

replies.author: @ScandinavianHeretic
replies.text:
@hataranneulastr5376 You're helping illustrate my point, even if unintentionally.

The comment in question isn‚Äôt about ignoring the Constitution - it‚Äôs about questioning whether it‚Äôs even feasible to apply full legal proceedings to every single immigration case on an unprecedented scale. That‚Äôs a logistical critique, not a rejection of law. It‚Äôs the kind of problem any administration would face when the system‚Äôs design collides with overwhelming volume.

If this is seen as proof of hostility toward due process, it might be worth looking at how earlier administrations dealt with similar challenges. The reaction seems less about principle and more about who‚Äôs currently in the spotlight.

Yes, due process matters. But any legal system has to balance ideals with implementation. If applying the rules exactly as written makes them unworkable, the real question becomes: how should a constitutional system adapt responsibly to complex, large-scale realities?

Your closing point concedes that perhaps large-scale deportation is ‚Äúagainst the spirit‚Äù of the Constitution. That‚Äôs a different claim from saying it‚Äôs illegal. So which is it - a moral concern or a legal one? It's important to be clear.

That‚Äôs why context matters. Without it, we drift into theatrical certainty, where moral outrage replaces serious thinking. And that does more damage to democratic dialogue than any poorly worded answer in a press gaggle.

No, he was expressing frustration that if constitutional guarantees apply in every single immigration case, then the system is functionally paralyzed by its own design. That may be an unpleasant observation, but it‚Äôs not a declaration of tyranny. It's a critique of logistical absurdity.

If you think this exposes some unique contempt for the rule of law, I‚Äôd invite you to review how prior administrations handled mass deportations or indefinite detentions. The inconsistency isn't in the President - it's in how selectively people apply their outrage.

As for your moral absolutism: yes, the Constitution grants due process. But due process, like any principle, must exist in tension with practicality. If the law can‚Äôt scale to reality, then the question isn‚Äôt whether someone ‚Äúhates the Constitution,‚Äù it‚Äôs whether the Constitution as applied is equipped to deal with scale, complexity, and security.

Your final point unwittingly gives the game away: maybe /\/\ass depor7ation is un-Constitutional in spirit. I see, so now we‚Äôre in the realm of ‚Äúspirit,‚Äù not law. But you began by saying he is breaking the law. Which is it?

Context matters. Without it, you‚Äôre not making an argument. You‚Äôre performing certainty to feel righteous. (Happy now Youtube? Sheesh, do you just not want people to talk? It really seems that way. Heaven forbid we talk things through! Calm down)

He wasn't rejecting the Constitution, he was pointing out that applying full legal process to every single immigration case at scale can break the system. That‚Äôs not tyranny, it‚Äôs a logistical problem.

replies.author: @hataranneulastr5376
@ScandinavianHeretic
replies.text:
@hataranneulastr5376 You say it's *literally illegal*, but what you actually mean is that *you believe it's unconstitutional*. Those aren't the same thing. Legality is decided by courts interpreting law, not by shouting "fifth amendment" in a comment section. The Constitution does not explicitly say how mass deportations must be handled, nor does it require the same procedures as in a criminal trial for every immigration case. That's why these issues go to court, because they are legally complex, not morally obvious.

Claiming that merely asking whether millions of individual trials are required is itself a violation of the Constitution is absurd. Questioning how a law applies is not the same as saying you don't have to follow it. That's basic reasoning.

And no, this situation isn't unique. The US has carried out mass deportations before, under both parties, often with contested procedures. If those actions were truly, unquestionably illegal, they would have been struck down as such at the time.

You're reacting emotionally and confusing your moral revulsion with legal fact. That may feel satisfying, but it's not an argument.

replies.text:
@ScandinavianHeretic Also,no, the Constitution does in fact state it's illegal in a very direct way. Let me quote for you if you're unwilling to check:
"No person shall be held to answer for a capital, or otherwise infamous crime, unless on a presentment or indictment of a Grand Jury, except in cases arising in the land or naval forces, or in the Militia, when in actual service in time of War or public danger; nor shall any person be subject for the same offence to be twice put in jeopardy of life or limb; nor shall be compelled in any criminal case to be a witness against himself, nor be deprived of life, liberty, or property, without due process of law; nor shall private property be taken for public use, without just compensation."
It's illegal to punish people (which includes deportation) without due process,which includes court trials. And this amendment applies to all people in the US jurisdiction, not just citizens (including imigrants, and illegal ones too). It also prohibits detaining them en masse without due process.
The current administration was unable to classify this situation as public danger to ignore due process,which already speaks volumes on how they can actually afford the time for trials but simply don't care. They tried picturing it as an actual time of war,too, which never went to court as of yet as far as I'm aware, but it's something they use in their rhetoric regardless

replies.author: @ScandinavianHeretic
replies.text:
@hataranneulastr5376 You‚Äôre tying yourself in knots to maintain outrage. First, you admit that the legality of the action would need to be determined in court. Then, in the same breath, you declare it ‚Äúliterally illegal‚Äù as if your personal reading of the Fifth Amendment is self-enforcing. That‚Äôs not how law works. Courts, not comment sections, determine illegality.

Second, you claim Trump ignored a court order. If that‚Äôs true - and that‚Äôs a big if - then cite the case. Not just your recollection of an article or a tweet, but the actual ruling. If a court order was defied and nothing happened, that‚Äôs a scandal of the system - not a proof that everything is ipso facto illegal just because you believe it should be.

Third, you claim Trump didn‚Äôt articulate himself well, so we should interpret his remarks in the worst possible light. That‚Äôs not a legal standard, it‚Äôs a partisan reflex. ‚ÄúHe didn‚Äôt say it the way I want, so I assume criminal intent.‚Äù That‚Äôs not argument. That‚Äôs hysteria.

Finally, you say due process could be done as a class action or a precedent-based method. Good - so you‚Äôre conceding that even you think the standard procedure doesn‚Äôt need to be applied identically in every case. In other words, the whole basis of Trump‚Äôs question - how to deal with scale - is valid.

This conversation would be more honest if you just said you loathe the man and believe he‚Äôs unfit for power. Fine. Argue that. But stop pretending your visceral dislike is a constitutional argument.

replies.author: @ScandinavianHeretic
replies.text:
‚Äã@hataranneulastr5376 You're misapplying the Fifth Amendment by treating deportation as if it's equivalent to criminal punishment. It isn't. Deportation is a civil action, not a criminal one, a distinction upheld by the Supreme Court for over a century, starting with Fong Yue Ting v. United States (1893). That isn't some legal trick; it's foundational to how immigration law works in the U.S.

Due process does apply to deportation, but not in the way you‚Äôre implying. It doesn't require jury trials, grand jury indictments, or the full apparatus of a criminal courtroom. Immigration courts exist precisely because this is a separate, civil system with its own procedures and standards.

Your repeated claim that mass deportations are ‚Äúliterally illegal‚Äù ignores both history and jurisprudence. The U.S. has carried out mass deportations under both Republican and Democratic administrations. Courts have judged these actions on procedural grounds, how they were carried out - not on the idea that deportation itself is unconstitutional unless done with full criminal trial rights. If your reading were correct, the entire immigration enforcement framework would collapse.

As for your claim that the administration tried to invoke ‚Äúwartime‚Äù powers. This part actually did happen, and it proves the opposite of your point. The Trump administration attempted to use the Alien Enemies Act to justify deporting Venezuelan nationals, calling certain gang activity an ‚Äúinvasion.‚Äù But the courts rejected that rationale precisely because there was no formal war or invasion. Judges ruled that due process still applied. So your example doesn't bolster your argument, it confirms that the judiciary is doing its job.

I suggest you stop pretending your anger is legal expertise. Immigration law is complex, filled with trade-offs, and structured to balance national sovereignty with individual rights. You loathe the man, fine, I get it, but then say that.

author: @eddieromanov
text:
I am the 5th generation descendant of German immigrants who came to the US in 1912. They thought that move was temporary.

To put it bluntly, I'm scared. I know that fear is part of the playbook but I still feel it. I don't know if or how we can turn this around over here. I don't know what or if I'll be able to do anything, really. I can't fight. I can't flee. I can't dare freeze. I can't use any of the tricks I've learned in therapy to cognitively reframe this because it's not anxiety. It is cold, hard, rational fear of something. Something that's already here, I'm seeing. So, I guess there's no point in being afraid of it anymore, is there? So, thank you for that.

author: @Comraid_Doge
text:
I recently rewatched ‚ÄúHow Societies Turn Cruel‚Äù after watching this video and I must say: it‚Äôs a scary time to be alive as a young American. 

I feel as though the democratic institutions that were promised to me as my birthright, are slipping through my fingers. 

My culture. My traditions. Trampled by folks who claim to care for American values but take shits on the constitution for fun.

At a certain point, you have to stand up, look your plans for the future, and realize that there can be no future while political extremists erode its very foundation.

I inch closer and closer to active political activism each day, at the expense of the future I actually wanted, and ask myself:

‚ÄúWhy? Why me, why now?‚Äù

And I suppose it‚Äôs like you said, we feel the weight of history and feel all the more weary for it. 

Thank you for your insight and strength in these trying times, I hope you keep up consistent content‚Äîyou are probably the reason why a great deal of folks fell out of the trap of extremism, and for that, I will be forever grateful. 

But I cannot in good conscience support Patreon. You wouldn‚Äôt happen to have another way to support you financially?

replies.author: @warheadsnation
replies.text:
There are further distinctions to be made.  Look at Hannah Arendt.  She argues that totalitarian parties have fundamentally different structure and goals from authoritarian parties.  The latter simply intend to amass a monopoly on state power.  Totalitarians look for their cult to replace every institution in society, to replace society itself.

The opposition to democracy presented by military juntas is very different from the opposition presented by populist extremists.  The former want the public simply silenced and apathetic.  The latter want total participation by all citizens in the mechanisms of oppression and control so that blood is on everyone's hands.

text: A question to ponder: At what point during 1930s Germany would violence against the government become acceptable?

replies.author: @TheDarthbinky
replies.text:
Fun fact - there was always political violence in Weimar Germany. 

The problem is that once Hitler came into power, he did that whole "Gleichschaltung" thing where the Nazis purged the government of opposition and then enlarged/empowered police and security agencies (including putting Hitler's personal bodyguards in charge of all of it). Once the entire state is oriented against you, it's hard to stand up to it. Especially in light of the Versailles Treaty restrictions on gun ownership (which Hitler ironically relaxed in 1938).

But this is the reason why I keep telling people to google "Gleichschaltung". Because... well... look around.

author: @lambdaambs2765
text: Well, I'm 18, I graduate in 10 days. Yet I feel like that accomplishment is completely overshadowed by never being able to see the freedoms I was promised. I've always believed in leftist teachings and equity for all, a better country for all. I came out as trans at 12 to a supportive family, and many people I knew outside of that bubble were hateful. The difference now, is rather than that hate being marginalized and small. It's almost half this country too stupid and too proud to see that a man, maybe not even going to live his 2nd term end; is determining the future of us youth. In the Pledge of Alliance I did every morning, "Indivisible, liberty and justice for all," was just something we must've blindly chanted--so many people I know have lost their way and forget that those 'immigrants', those black communities, us trans folks, LGBTQ+, and even themselves at points; are humans too. What type of human creates cruelty quite like this? Divides a country found on openness and morals of freedom? Fascists. Dictators, people who want their word to be law. I want to fight, I'm not afraid to lay down my life to salvage the American Dream for people younger than I. But the odds are, as a Native American, they'd just lump me in with the 'immigrants' and ship me off somewhere to die. Aren't I too young to die for human rights? So here I wait. Waiting quietly, with lack of options for it to be my turn on the chopping block, I'm not white or cis afterall. What place do I have in an America that is built for the white straight man? I wish we could have America for all, that white straight man too, as long as everyone does their part I say. But the rights aren't for rights I suppose. May God, our true God, not the one the rights claim to pray to nightly; have mercy on us astray Americans when our judgment comes to pass.

author: @ArmchairMagpie
text:
I was not even aware of still being subscribed here, and I used to be signed up via Patreon. But I do agree that it is difficult to keep track of all insanities launched at once. But I have watched a video by Mallen Baker recently which illustrates why Trump will fail, but why its successor could be worse. The problem is that people try to justify it calling fascism based on factors, whereas the opposition, to use a kinder word, doesn't shy away from calling everyone opposing them a Marxist or communist. We need to loosen up a little. The categories are made by us, we can adapt and expand a little. 

Trump is only a puppet, that lives in his own made up bubble, where he thinks he will be remembered well. The differences to other post-fascist leaders are:

a) he will not be the one earning legitimacy due to lack of own competence
b) he is not the one forming a coherent party ideology (he has too many whisperers for that)
c) he has too many weaknesses not to just serve as a puppet for the actual masters in the background, which will eventually be split into a secular hypercapitalist faction and one a hyper-religious nationalist faction bend on eliminating every individual freedoms, for now, they have some truce in place, but cracks are already beginning to show

But his own party ideologues will have nominated a more competent successor in no time before his body is cold. He will get some faux legitimacy in that his name will be uttered  to appease the rabid crowd that is still crying until he gets willfully forgotten. The reason they are trying to scram as much as possible into his presidency is possible is not just they need to throw political flash-bang grenades, they want the successor to land softly in a prepared bed. 

The best thing one needs to remember if he wants to effectively counter that is that he doesn't get caught in a spider-web of lengthy individual battles, but to fight the movement as a whole. The scalpel is good for what it does, but every so often it's good to remember that there is a place for grapeshot.
